awd_titl_txt: Design and Control Principles for Mobile Health Care Operations Management -- The Case of Asthma Control
awd_abstract_narration:
In 2005, 6.5 million children in the United States suffered from asthma, a chronic respiratory disease characterized by periods of difficulty in breathing. Childhood asthma places severe burden on communities through emergency room visits and hospitalization due to lack of access to routine and continuous health care.  Non-profit organizations, such as the Mobile C.A.R.E. Foundation (MCF), provide mobile care for childhood asthma through periodic visits to schools in metropolitan areas across the United States.  Mobile care entails a complex array of operational decisions, including patient scheduling and capacity allocation, which are critical to ensuring that community health objectives are met effectively. This research investigates the link between operational decisions in a mobile environment and their impact on the community health outcomes.  Three critical aspects of the research setting, chronic care, mobile delivery and non-profit environment, necessitate the creation of a new family of operations research models for planning, scheduling and resource allocation in health care operations compared to those developed for conventional settings such as primary care clinics and hospital outpatient departments. 

This research will have significant impact at many levels.  Operations research techniques can greatly improve the ability of MCF to provide essential health services to children from underserved communities in the Chicago region in a sustainable manner. Such operational improvement is especially critical during an economic downturn.  The insights will be used to create a set of operational best practices to be disseminated to other organizations that operate mobile clinics for chronic conditions beyond asthma. The new operations models will contribute to the growing field of health care operations, and stimulate research in settings as varied as mobile health care for diabetes and for homeless and elderly, and mobile HIV clinics in Africa. The research will actively engage graduate and undergraduate students in analytical research and field work.

por.por_cntn:
This project in community-based health care has focused on scheduling challenges unique to such settings, motivated by a collaboration with Chicago-based provider, The Mobile C.A.R.E. Foundation (MCF). Disease management programs, such as the school-based asthma program provided by MCF, have emerged as a cost-effective approach to treat chronic diseases; and such settings lead to novel applications of operations research.

We have developed an integrated capacity allocation model to assist MCF with their scheduling of patients to asthma vans that incorporates clinical (patient disease progression) and operational (van capacity constraint) aspects. We solve this allocation problem using mathematical models, where the provider decides which patients to schedule at the beginning of each period. Intuitively, one would expect to schedule “sicker” patients before “healthier" patients; however, in this complex settings in which the health of a patient is defined along multiple dimensions, defining “sick” and “healthy” patients is challenging. In our work, we derive a quantitative measure to compare patients. We characterize the optimal patient scheduling policy in special cases using this measure. Additionally, we employ this measure to design an easy-to-implement myopic heuristic that is provably optimal in special cases of the problem. Computational experiments suggest that this approach can improve the health gains at the community level by up to 15% over the current policy. 

Over the course of the project, we have worked with closely with MCF to apply our findings in practice with teams of graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and undergraduates, giving opportunities to many students to engage in research at the intersection of operations research and community-based healthcare. We developed a case study based on this project which has been adopted in operations research/management health care classes, including a Ph.D. elective on humanitarian logistics and a university-wide undergraduate elective on analytics for social good at Northwestern.  PI Deo has introduced this case into his courses at the Indian School of Business. We have augmented the case study over the course of the project to include a generated dataset that mimics some characteristics of MCF without disclosing patient data.  As such, students can work with data to develop models related to the case study.  A team of undergraduates analyzed possible parallel booking strategies for the organization. We built on these ideas with a post-doctoral fellow to formalize policies to integrate virtual appointments.  This work has developed methods to evaluate the effectiveness of virtual appointments relative to traditional office visits and introduced policies to allocate both types of appointments.

In related work with other collaborators, we explore the potential benefits of monitoring operational data (e.g., appointment adherence) within the newly-adopted electronic medical records system at MCF. We consider patient differentiation along several dimensions, including appointment adherence and disease severity, when scheduling. We show that patient differentiation can lead to improved schedule adherence (lower patient no-shows) and improved community health outcomes. We identify settings in which simple, easy-to-use policies can produce schedules that are comparable in quality to those obtained with an optimization-based approach.  We have also worked with collaborators in airline operations research to show the parallels in stochastic scheduling between community-based health care scheduling and airline scheduling, as the underlying pricing problems in both settings share common characteristics.
